content: highlight account in left side of main window, rightclick and select 'settings'. on next pane, click 'server settings' in left pane. If it says 'smtp.gmail.com' that is the reason you are not receiving messages, as that is the outgoing server, not the incoming one. Please post what you see. thank you.

content: The message comes up because Google insists on approval of all email setups that use email clients, whether Thunderbird or others. Once confirmed, Google stores a password unique to the PC, allowing regular access.
creator: davidsk

content:
Puoi dirmi come hai fatto questa copia e quali file contiene di preciso. Inoltre parliamo di account POP3 o IMAP?

Se gli account sono POP posso suggerirti questa procedura:

  1. Sull'HD esterno crea una cartella apposita
  2. Copia in questa cartella i file mbox di Thunderbird (leggi qui per capire come recuperarli -> https://support.mozilla.org/it/questions/1378215#answer-1508370)
  3. Avvia Thunderbird e vai in Menu > Nuovo > Crea account di fee per creare un nuovo account
  4. Vai ora in Menu > Impostazioni account, trova sulla sinistra l'account appena creato e cambia l'impostazione presente alla voce Cartella locale indicando il percorso della cartella creata sopra
  5. Riavviando Thunderbird, in corrispondenza de nuovo account dovresti ritrovare i messaggi di posta archiviati.

Se gli account sono IMAP questa procedura non funziona bene. In tal caso puoi provare con questa procedura -> https://forum.mozillaitalia.org/index.php?topic=78322.msg541747#msg541747
creator: @next

content: Assuming you use 115, rightclick on unified tool bar and click customize. Then, drag the 'view' icon to the toolbar and click save. Now, just click it and one option is 'unread.' Click that and only unread messages will appear.
creator: davidsk

Try starting in troubleshoot mode https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/kb/troubleshoot-mode-thunderbird#w_starting-thunderbird-in-troubleshoot-mode

content: Assuming you use Windows, delete c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird and c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\local\thunderbird and start over with a installing thunderbird.
creator: davidsk

content: That may be a server setup issue. If you share detailed smtp settings, someone may offer a suggestion.

content: My first concern is seeing server name begins with 'pop', yet error message indicates imap. Maybe if you post server settings, some ideas will surface. Also, it may help to review that each account is using a separate SMTP server, as that is a common issue when users have more than one account on the domain.
creator: davidsk

content: This may not work, but I've seen many email provider changes in past year. Try this: smtp.xplore.net with port 465 and SSL/TLS if that doesn't work, try smtp.xplore.net with port 587 and STARTTLS
creator: davidsk

content: You can run both from one Thunderbird. Each will have it's own folders and they act independent from each other.
creator: davidsk

content: The simplest way is this: - on old PC, exit Thunderbird if it's running - copy profile from c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird to USB stick - on new PC, have thunderbird installed but not running - copy the thunderbird folder on USB stick to c:\users\<yourid>\appdata\roaming to overwrite the existing thunderbird folder - start thunderbird and all should be there.
creator: davidsk
